Award.AwardTitle: CIF: Medium: Collaborative Research: Tracking low-dimensional information in data streams and dynamical systems

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Computer & Info Scie & Enginr

Division.LongName: Division of Computing and Communication Foundations

Award.AbstractNarration:
Many applications of significant societal impact are modeled by
complex dynamical system behavior, including the (life, physical
and social) sciences, medicine, economics, law, urban development,
international politics and global conflict. Fortunately, recent
advances in sensor technology have allowed observation of these
phenomena at an unprecedented scale. Unfortunately, the volume and
complexity of available data present many challenges to extracting
meaningful information about these systems. Low-dimensional models
serve as a useful structure for understanding the information in
high-dimensional signals and systems. However, this information
often changes over time, and so these models can further be
improved by exploiting temporal dynamics. This project is concerned
with developing new methods for tracking changing low-dimensional
structure in data streams and dynamical systems, particularly in
settings where the observations may be missing, incomplete,
corrupted, or compressed.

The first research aim in this project is to develop new and
substantially improve existing techniques for tracking
low-dimensional structure and, in particular, to extend tracking
capabilities far beyond conventional signals to much more general
data sets with intrinsic low-dimensional structure. A second
research aim is to develop new tools for tracking low-dimensional
structure in systems jointly with estimating the content of
time-varying signals and data sets. A third research aim is
concerned with higher-dimensional and more complex dynamical
systems, and the goal is to develop improved methods that exploit
low-dimensional structure to perform quantitative and qualitative
analysis in systems that are too complex and high-dimensional for
system identification. In a fourth, educational aim, accessible
K-12 outreach materials are being developed for dissemination
through an online digital library.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Many applications of significant societal impact are modeled by complex dynamical system behavior, including the (life, physical and social) sciences, medicine, economics, law, urban development, international politics and global conflict. Fortunately, recent advances in sensor technology have allowed observation of these phenomena at an unprecedented scale.  Unfortunately, the volume and complexity of available data present many challenges to extracting meaningful information about these systems. Low-dimensional models serve as a useful structure for understanding the information in high-dimensional signals and systems. However, this information often changes over time, and so these models can further be improved by exploiting temporal dynamics. This project was concerned with developing new methods for tracking changing low-dimensional structure in data streams, data matrices, and dynamical systems, particularly in settings where the observations may be missing, incomplete, corrupted, or compressed.

A major research thrust focused on algorithms for capturing data matrices and related structures such as subspace models or principal components, particularly in streaming settings or where prior information is available. First, we studied the recovery of matrices with prior information, as might be available in a streaming scenario where a prior matrix estimate can be used to inform the recovery at the current time. We studied a weighted algorithm for incorporating prior information into matrix recovery. We developed theory and experiments to show how this algorithm outperforms unweighted matrix recovery, where no prior information is exploited. Second, we studied a two-phase algorithm for matrix completion, in which leverage scores are identified in a first phase that uses uniform random sampling, and then employed in a second phase that uses nonuniform sampling. Third, we developed theory for identifying active subspaces from random samples of a data set. Active subspaces correspond to the principal directions of the gradient of a function, and identifying these subspaces from inexpensive random point samples (rather than expensive gradient computations) can be useful for accelerating scientific computations that depend on many input parameters. Fourth, we introduced and studied a streaming subspace estimation algorithm called SNIPE that processes streaming blocks of incomplete data to identify a low-dimensional subspace.

A second major research thrust focused on studying the stability of delay-coordinate mappings in the reconstruction of dynamical systems from time series observations. Delay-coordinate mapping is an effective and widely used technique for reconstructing and analyzing the dynamics of a nonlinear system based on time-series outputs. The efficacy of delay-coordinate mapping has long been supported by Takens' embedding theorem, which guarantees that delay-coordinate maps use the time-series output to provide a reconstruction of the hidden state space that is a one-to-one embedding of the system's attractor. While this topological guarantee ensures that distinct points in the reconstruction correspond to distinct points in the original state space, it does not characterize the quality of this embedding or illuminate how the specific parameters affect the reconstruction. We extended Takens' result by establishing conditions under which delay-coordinate mapping is guaranteed to provide a stable embedding of a system's attractor. Our theoretical findings give guidance to choosing system parameters, echoing the trade-off between irrelevancy and redundancy that has been heuristically investigated in the literature.

A third major research thrust focused on identifying fundamental properties of engineered and geophysical systems from limited amounts of sensor data. One problem in this thrust has been that of modal analysis of a vibrating structure, minimizing the number of samples that must be collected from a wireless sensor network to characterize the health of that structure. Such work has relevance in structural health monitoring and relies on characterizing the dynamics of the structure from limited amounts of data. Relatedly, we proposed an algorithm for spectral estimation that involves searching for the peaks of the dual polynomial corresponding to a certain nuclear norm minimization problem, and we showed that this algorithm is in fact equivalent to the classical MUSIC algorithm for spectral estimation. We also derived theoretical guarantees for an atomic norm minimization algorithm to solve a problem of parameter estimation of complex exponentials from their modulations with unknown waveforms. This work has a variety of potential applications, including super-resolution with unknown point spread functions and frequency estimation in damping. Another problem in this thrust has been that of seismic interferometry, which allows the Green’s function between two points to be estimated based on vibrational data at those two locations. Such data volumes are often immense, and to reduce the burden of data collection, we have proposed a compressive technique that requires only random spectral samples of each signal.

Finally, in a fourth, educational thrust, accessible K-12 outreach materials were developed for dissemination through a peer-reviewed online digital library. These materials were also delivered to/shared with a teacher’s workshop, summer camps, and a local school for dyslexic students. This project also supported the training and education of Graduate Research Assistants.
